tiles.label: I Have a Student I Am Concerned About
Anxious
tiles.description:
[picture anxiety]
Let’s face it: anxiety doesn’t feel good.  But, anxiety IS normal.  Feeling anxious is an expectable and healthy (albeit unpleasant) response to life’s stressors. . .and can even be helpful sometimes.  If someone is anxious about a big test, they might study more.  If someone is anxious that they’ve done something wrong, they might go out of their way to make amends.  If someone is anxious about getting hurt, they might take extra precautions to protect themselves.  For some, though, anxiety can go from helpful to harmful.  Generally speaking, anxiety that is disproportionate to the situation, does not go away after the threat is gone, or makes it hard to fully engage in daily activities may be a sign of an anxiety disorder.
There are many anxiety disorders, including generalized anxiety, social anxiety, test anxiety, and phobias.  It is important to remember that anxiety may present differently in different people.

warningSigns.primaryHeader: If someone is feeling anxious, you might notice that the person:
primarySigns: Is worrying more than the situation might otherwise call for
Tends to catastrophize, or assume the very worst might happen
Appears physically tense or jittery
Avoids the things that make them worry, like completing an assignment, participating in class, or talking to their professors
Has an overwhelming need for reassurance or feedback
Wants to be in control
warningSigns.secondaryHeader: Someone experiencing anxiety may also experience:

dosDonts.do: Validate how the person is feeling
doBullets: It sounds like you're really anxious.
I can tell that you're anxious about _________.
What specifically is worrying you?
dosDonts.dont: Dismiss or try to talk the person out of their feelings
dontBullets: There’s nothing to worry about.  Everything is going to be fine
If you stopped worrying so much, you’d feel better

dosDonts.do: Be empathetic
doBullets: I’m sorry that you’re having a hard time right now.
Or, say nothing at all.  Allow the person to experience and share their feelings without fear of judgement.
dontBullets: Worrying is a waste of time.
Everyone is anxious nowadays. . .you have to get over it.

dosDonts.do: Help the person to help themselves
doBullets: Let’s look at this in the big picture.
What are the things you can control in this situation?
Why don’t we take a moment to breathe?
I can connect you with resources to help – the University Counseling Center, tutoring, Financial Aid, an advisor, Housing, Replenish, the Registrar’s Office, etc.
What usually works for you when you’re feeling this anxious?
Do you have people who can support you when you’re feeling this way?
dosDonts.dont: Jump in to “fix” the problem for them. . .avoidance can sometimes make anxiety worse in the long-run.
dontBullets: Don’t worry. . . we’ll do whatever you want/need to feel better.
You should go to a therapist, do yoga, mediate, take a bubble bath, etc.

bullets.title: Validate the Student’s Anxiety
bullets.description: Validate the student’s anxiety by saying things like, "It sounds like you’re feeling really anxious", rather than, "There’s no reason to worry – everything is going to be fine".

bullets.title: Show Empathy
bullets.description: Show the student empathy by saying things like, "I’m sorry that you’re feeling so anxious", rather than, "Worrying is a waste of time".

bullets.title: Help the Student Help Themselves
bullets.description: Help the student help themself by taking deep breaths together or saying things like, "What usually works for you when you’re feeling this anxious?", rather than trying to fix it for them. Remember, it’s not your responsibility to provide treatment or find a "quick fix".

bullets.title: Share Resources
bullets.description: Encourage the student to use the resources available to them. The University Counseling Center offers online screenings and other self-help resources in addition to clinical services. Resources specific to students’ individual needs, including Disability Support Resources, Financial Aid, Tutoring, academic advising, and others, can be found using the Resources button on the home page. If you are still concerned about the student, you can also make a CARE referral through the Dean of Students Office.

body.header: Click here if someone is having a panic attack
body.body:
[header Stay calm]
- Getting anxious or upset yourself will only exacerbate the situation.
[header Help the student regulate their breathing]
-  Model regulated breathing by asking them to slowly breathe in and out with you
-   Encourage them to breathe in for 4 seconds, hold for 4 seconds, breathe out for 4 seconds, hold for 4 seconds and repeat. This is called box breathing.
[header Encourage them to use grounding techniques]
-    Have the student sit down in a chair with their feet on the floor.  Offer the student a glass of water, if able.  One of the following grounding techniques may also be helpful:
-Ask them to describe an object in the room in great detail.  It might be an object that they hold or one that they can see.
- Gently encourage them to identify 5 things that they can see, 4 things that they can feel, 3 things that they can hear, 2 things that they can smell, and 1 thing that they can taste as a way to recenter their attention.
[header Say these reassuring things]
-    You can get through this
- Just concentrate on your breathing
- Stay in the present
- This feeling will not last forever
- You are safe
[header Connect with help]
-    If the student is in need of immediate assistance, connect with available emergency services using the “I Have an Emergency” button below.
- If the student is not in need of immediate assistance, additional resources that may be helpful can be found on the [link /home, placeholder: Home Page].”

tiles.label: Depressed
tiles.description:
[picture depression]
Most of us feel down sometimes – it might be when someone has hurt our feelings, or after a breakup or the loss of a loved one.  Usually, those feelings are manageable or go away with time.  Depression, though, is more than just having “the blues” for a few days.  Depression is a persistent feeling of sadness, apathy, or hopelessness, and it isn’t always in response to something bad that’s happened.  Many people feel depressed despite the positive things in their lives.  Depression can impact the way people feel, as well as the way that they think and the things that they do – often in ways that feel outside of their control.
There are different forms of depression, such as seasonal depression, dysthymia, postpardum depression, and bipolar disorder.  It is important to remember depression may present differently in different people.

warningSigns.primaryHeader: If someone is feeling depressed, you might notice that the person:
primarySigns: Seems “down” or “blue”
Lacks energy or appears tired, regardless of how much they sleep
Isn’t going to class or work regularly
Is less interested in things that they used to enjoy, such as spending time with friends
Sounds pessimistic or hopeless
Has gained or lost a significant amount of weight
warningSigns.secondaryHeader: Someone experiencing depression may also experience:
secondarySigns: Changes in their sleep patterns – sleeping more or less than usual

dosDonts.do: Validate how the person is feeling
doBullets: It sounds like you’re having a really hard time right now.
It’s okay to feel the way you feel.
I noticed ___________.  I wanted to check in to see how you’re doing.
dosDonts.dont: Dismiss or try to talk the person out of their feelings
dontBullets: You don’t have any reason to be depressed.  Lots of people have it worse.
Just focus on the positive. Think happy thoughts!
Snap out of it.

dosDonts.do: Be empathetic
doBullets: I’m sorry that you’re feeling this way.
I may not understand exactly what you’re going through, but you’re not alone in this.
You are important, and I care.
dontBullets: Feeling sorry for yourself isn’t going to help.
Just stop it -- you’re in control of your own feelings.

dosDonts.do: Help the person to help themselves
doBullets: I can help connect you with resources to help - the University Counseling Center, tutoring, Financial Aid, an advisor, Housing, Replenish, the Registrar's Office, etc.
Is there anything that helps when you're feeling down like this?
Do you have people who can support you when you're feeling this way?
dosDonts.dont: Jump in to “fix” the problem for them. . . .
dontBullets: Everything will be okay, I promise.
Don’t worry. . . we’ll do whatever you want/need to feel better.
You should go to therapy, exercise, cut out sugar, etc.

dosDonts.do: Ask the person if they are suicidal if you are concerned for their safety.
dosDonts.doLast: [link /guide, placeholder: I have a student who may be suicidal.]

bullets.title: Check in with the Student
bullets.description: Check in on the student by saying things like, “I noticed ___________ and wanted to check in with you”, rather than ignoring warning signs of depression.

bullets.title: Show Empathy
bullets.description: Show the student empathy by saying things like, “I’m sorry that you’re feeling this way” and “I may not understand what you are going through, but I care”, rather than, “Just focus on the positive; you have so much to be happy for”.

bullets.title: Help the Student Help Themselves
bullets.description: Help the student help themself by saying things like, “Is there anything that helps when you’re feeling down?” or “Do you have people who can support you when you’re feeling this way?”, rather than trying to fix it for them. Remember, it’s not your responsibility to provide treatment or a “quick fix”.

tiles.description:
[picture suicide]
In the United States, someone attempts suicide every 27 seconds.  While suicide is the 10th leading cause of death nationally, it is the 2nd leading cause of death among college students – and rates are on the rise.  Suicide may be difficult to talk about, but the warning signs should never be ignored.  Whereas most are not trained to treat those who are experiencing suicidality, anyone can help save a life.

warningSigns.primaryHeader: If someone is feeling suicidal, you might notice that the person:
primarySigns: Seems depressed, or their mood has otherwise changed significantly
Expresses feelings of hopelessness

Shares thoughts of suicide, such as: “I wish I were dead”, “I can’t go on anymore”, “Everyone would be better off without me here”,“Nobody would care if I weren’t around anymore”,“I will kill myself if I don’t pass this class, my partner breaks up with me, etc.”
Is isolating themselves from others
Is engaging in concerning behaviors, such as giving away their possessions, harming themselves,     acquiring weapons, etc.
Has recently experienced a traumatic life event, such as a breakup, failing a class, or the loss of a loved one

dosDonts.do: ALWAYS ASK someone directly if you are concerned that they may be suicidal.
doBullets: Are you thinking of killing yourself?
Has it gotten so bad that you’ve considered suicide?
I’ve noticed _________.  Sometimes when that happens, people wish that they were dead.  Have you been feeling that way?
dosDonts.doLast: If you are unable or too uncomfortable to ask someone if they are feeling suicidal, find someone else who can.  A student’s life may depend on it.
dosDonts.dont: Ignore warning signs of suicide or assume that someone else will intervene.

dosDonts.do: Be empathetic
doBullets: Thank you for reaching out/talking to me.
I’m sorry that you’re hurting.
dontBullets: Your life’s not that bad. . .a lot of people have it far worse than you do.
You don’t really mean that.
Everyone will be mad/upset at you if you kill yourself.
Suicide is selfish.

dosDonts.do: Instill hope. . .hope saves lives
doBullets: I know it may not feel like it right now, but this can get better.
I care about you, and I want you to live.
I know how to find someone who can help.
dontBullets: There’s nothing worth dying for.
Just try to forget about it.
You should go to therapy, mediate, exercise, buy a sun lamp, etc.

dosDonts.do: Connect the person with resources
doBullets: If someone says that they are suicidal, or you have reason to suspect that they may harm themselves, do not wait to intervene.  Help is available 24-hours a day.  Connect them with available emergency services using the “I Have an Emergency” button below.
If the student is not feeling suicidal but is struggling with their mental health or another concern, additional campus resources are available.

bullets.title: Address Your Concerns Directly
bullets.description: If you have any reason to suspect that a student is feeling suicidal, ALWAYS ask the student directly. You can say things like, "Are you thinking of killing yourself?" or "Has it gotten so bad that you’ve considered suicide?". If you are unable or too uncomfortable to ask, find someone who can – a student’s life may depend on it.

bullets.title: Show Empathy
bullets.description: Show the student empathy by saying things like, "Thank you for reaching out to me" or "I’m sorry that you’re hurting", rather than, "Don’t say that" or "Suicide is selfish – think of how badly you’d hurt other people".

bullets.title: Instill Hope
bullets.description: Instill hope by saying things like, "I know it may not feel like it right now, but this can get better" or "I care about you and want you to live". Hope saves lives.

bullets.title: Act Immediately
bullets.description: Connect the student with appropriate resources. Do not wait to act. Click the “I Have an Emergency” button below for how to respond to student mental health emergencies day or night, on-campus or off.

tiles.label: Threatening or may harm others
tiles.description: Campus safety has moved into the foreground at academic institutions across the country.  Recent events and the constant streaming of tragedies from around globe have heightened fears for many.  While it is impossible to accurately predict who might act on concerning behaviors, research has found some commonalities among those who are threatening or might otherwise cause harm to others.  It is important to note that alone, or even in combination, many of the warning signs below are not directly related to risk.  Use your judgement, reach out for help when needed, and err on the side of your safety and the safety of the campus community.

warningSigns.primaryHeader: If someone is behaving in a threatening way or at risk of harming others, you might notice that the person:
primarySigns: Expresses feelings of anger, rage, or persecution toward a person, group, or society in general
Engages in concerning behaviors, such as acquiring weapons, breaking laws, or taking risks with their lives or the lives of others
Threatens violence or shares thoughts of violence against others
Is withdrawn or socially isolated
Seems depressed, or their mood has otherwise changed significantly
Yells at or otherwise attempts to intimidate others
Have a history of violence against people or animals
Have a history of conflict with authority
secondarySigns: Have a history of violence against people or animals
Have a history of conflict with authority

dosDonts.do:
If there is immediate danger, remove yourself from the situation and contact GVPD or 911.
If there is no immediate danger, refer to the following DOs and DONTs.
dontBullets: Peak anger usually lasts 20-30 seconds.

dosDonts.do: Allow the student to tell you what they are feeling, even if you disagree or are concerned by it
doBullets: I hear that you are feeling ________.
I’m sorry that you feel ________.
Or, say nothing at all.  Allow the person to experience and share their feelings without fear of judgement.
dosDonts.dont: Ignore or minimize how the person is feeling
dontBullets: Don’t say that. . . .you’ll get in trouble.
Oh, you don’t mean that.
Whatever you’re upset about is not that big of a deal.

dosDonts.do: Be firm and set limits
doBullets: I will be willing to speak with you as soon as you lower your voice.
If you continue to ________, I will have to ask you to leave the room.
I am feeling uncomfortable with ________ and am going to have to ask you not to do that again.
I am unable to do ________.  If you would like to discuss this further, you can contact ________.
dontBullets: It’s your own fault this happened.
Maybe if you had done ________, things would be different.
You’re crazy.

dosDonts.do: Focus on resolving the situation
doBullets: Is there something that I can do to be helpful?
I can connect you with resources to help – the University Counseling Center, tutoring, Financial Aid, an advisor, Housing, Replenish, the Registrar’s Office, etc.
What usually works for you when you’re feeling this upset?
dontBullets: Remain calm. Raising your voice or arguing back can further escalate an already difficult situation.

dosDonts.do: Act
doBullets: File a CARE Report if there is no immediate danger and you would like a member of the Division of Student Affairs staff to check-in with the person.
Remove yourself from the situation and contact GVPD or 911 immediately if you are concerned for you safety or the safety of others at any time.

howToHelp.description: If you or others are in any immediate danger, remove yourself from the situation and contact 911. If you do not believe that there is concern for your or others’ safety, then. . . .

bullets.title: Allow the Student to Share Their Feelings
bullets.description: Allow the student to share their feelings, even if you disagree by saying things like, “I hear that you are feeling ____________” rather than, “Don’t say that” or “There’s no reason to be so angry”.

bullets.title: Respond Calmly
bullets.description: Respond calmly and set limits by saying things like, “I will be willing to speak with you as soon as you lower your voice” or “If you continue to ____________, I will have to ask you to leave the room”, rather than escalating the situation. Avoid arguing, raising your voice, or placing blame or guilt on the student.

bullets.title: Remain Focused
bullets.description: Remain focused on the situation at hand by saying things like, “I will do what I can to address this concern” or directing the student to an administrator or campus resource that can address the issue. Resources specific to students’ needs can be found using the Resources button on the home page.

bullets.title: Prioritize Safety
bullets.description: If you have any concerns for your, the student’s, or others’ immediate or future safety after engaging with the student, call 911 immediately. If there are no safety concerns, you can file a CARE referral through the Dean of Students Office.

tiles.label: Unusual or bizarre behavior
tiles.description:
[picture psychosis]
Interacting with someone who speaks or behaves in a way that is unusual can feel frightening. Contrary to what is portrayed in movies and the media, those who experience disruptions to reality are not inherently more dangerous than others. The fact is that disorders that alter the way people think and experience the world are more common than most believe. These disorders often emerge in early adulthood. For some, that means while they are in college.
There are many reasons that someone may be exhibiting bizarre or unusual behavior, including a psychotic disorder, a psychotic episode related to another mental health disorder, recreational use or drugs or alcohol, an unintended side-effect of a prescribed medication, nutritional deficits, dehydration, and lack of sleep. It is important to remember that symptoms may present differently in different people.

resourcesRelevant.body: The University Counseling Center offers free mental health services to currently enrolled students.  All students are seen within 48 hours for an initial screening, and crisis appointments are available same-day.  To see frequently asked questions about mental health services on campus, visit the [link /faq, placeholder: FAQ button].

resourcesRelevant.body: If you have reached out to the student with support and resource and the student is in need of additional assistance, you can file a [link https://cm.maxient.com/reportingform.php?GrandValley&layout_id=2, placeholder: CARE Report].  A member of the Division of Student Affairs will review the report and follow-up as appropriate. resourcesRelevant.body: The Grand Valley Police Department and other local law enforcement authorities are available to assist if you concerned for someone’s safety or ability to make safe decisions on their own behalf.

warningSigns.primaryHeader: If someone is experiencing a psychotic episode or their thought processes are otherwise impaired, you might notice that the person:
primarySigns: Seems confused or disoriented
Is disorganized in their speech – what they are saying may not make sense, or their thoughts may be difficult to follow
Appears to be seeing, hearing, or experiencing things that others around them are not
Believes something that you have reason to suspect is untrue
Has either heightened emotions or appears to be void of emotion
Is not maintaining hygiene or self-care
secondarySigns: Struggle to perform the activities of daily living, such as going to work or school
Sleep far more or far less than usual

dosDonts.do: Be gentle and calm
doBullets: Speak in a quiet/low voice.
Use short, simple sentences.
Repeat yourself if necessary.
dontBullets: Raising your voice or having a strong emotional response may only escalate what the person is experiencing.

dosDonts.do: Empathize
doBullets: I don’t know what you are experiencing.  Can you describe it to me?
I can only imagine how difficult this must be for you.
I care about you and will do what I can to help.
dontBullets: You’re crazy or You’re psycho.
What is wrong with you?
That’s not true. . .you’re just telling yourself that.

dosDonts.do: Focus on feelings rather than facts, if their thoughts seem disordered or disorganized
doBullets: How are you feeling right now?
You must be feeling very _______ right now.
I can see why you feel the way that you do.
dosDonts.dont: Try to correct the person’s thinking or convince them to think differently
dontBullets: Snap out of it.
What you’re saying doesn’t make any sense!
No, that thing is not true, and here are the reasons why:

dosDonts.do: Connect the student with someone who can help
doBullets: If you believe that a student may be decompensating or have seen concerning changes in their behavior over time, file a CARE Report.

Refer the student to the University Counseling Center.  Same-day crisis appointments are available, and faculty and staff are welcome to bring students to the office and share their concerns.  Faculty and staff may also call to consult with a member of the UCC staff over the phone.
If you are concerned that the student is unable to make decisions on their own behalf or may be a danger to themselves or others, please click the “I Have an Emergency” button below.
dontBullets: Bizarre or otherwise unusual behavior can be the result of a serious medical or mental health condition.  The sooner that it is recognized and treated, the better for the student.

bullets.title: Remain Calm
bullets.description: Remain calm. Speak in a gentle, quiet voice and use short, simple sentences. Avoid panicking as it may escalate the situation.

bullets.title: Show Empathy
bullets.description: Show the student empathy by saying things like, “I don’t know what you’re experiencing. . . Can you describe it to me?” or “I care about you and will do what I can to help”, rather than, “What’s wrong with you?” or “What you’re saying doesn’t make sense”.

bullets.title: Focus on Feelings
bullets.description: Focus on feelings rather than facts by saying things like, “How are you feeling?” or “What would help you feel better right now?”. Avoid trying to correct misperceptions or statements that may be untrue.

bullets.title: Connect with Support
bullets.description: Connect the student with someone who can help. If you are concerned that the student is unable to make decisions on their own behalf or is in any danger, click the “I Have an Emergency” button below. If the student is not experiencing an emergency, you can file a CARE referral or refer the student to the University Counseling Center for additional support.

tiles.header: I have a student who is NOT COMING TO CLASS
tiles.body:
A student may not be attending class for a variety of reasons – they may be ill, attending to a personal emergency, in the process of withdrawal, or otherwise unable.  If you are concerned about a student who is not attending class, you can do two things:
- Reach out to the student personally.  Express your concern, share available resources, and work with the student, if appropriate, to transition back to class.
- File a [link https://cm.maxient.com/reportingform.php?GrandValley&layout_id=2, placeholder: CARE Report].  The Student Support Manager will reach out to the student to provide support and resources.

tiles.header: I have a student who has shared that they have a DISABILITY
tiles.body:
If a student is requesting accommodations for a disability, they will need a memorandum, or “memo”, from the Disability Support Resources office.  While faculty and staff have the right to address individual student concerns as they believe appropriate, official accommodations are determined by DSR and outlined in the memo that students receive.  In order to receive a memo, students must self-disclose their disability and provide required documentation.
 If a student says that they have a disability but is not registered with Disability Support Resources, you can direct them to the [link https://www.gvsu.edu/dsr/, placeholder: DSR website] for additional information.
Students may also call [phone 616-331-2490] to schedule an appointment with a DSR advisor.

tiles.header: I have a student who I’m concerned is USING ALCOHOL OR DRUGS
tiles.body:
The University offers resources to help students who are struggling with alcohol or drug use.  Students may be referred to Alcohol and Other Drugs Services, or AOD, for information, support, and treatment.  Through AOD Services, the University Counseling Center provides prevention and outreach programming, as well as individual and group counseling for substance-related concerns.  Meetings are also available on-campus for students and community members in active recovery.  To learn more about AOD Services, students can visit the [link https://www.gvsu.edu/aod, placeholder: AOD Website] or call
 [phone 616-331-2537].

If you are concerned that a student is under the influence of alcohol or drugs in class or a meeting, please call GVPD to share your observations.  Signs may include slurred speech, difficulty with balance, dilated pupils, or loss of consciousness, among others.  Even if a student is not exhibiting these symptoms, a call to GVPD is still warranted if you are concerned that they are intoxicated.

tiles.header: I have a student who has experienced SEXUAL ASSAULT/PARTNER VIOLENCE
tiles.body:
Services are available to students who have experienced sexual assault, stalking, or intimate partner violence.  Students may be referred to the Victim Advocate for support and resources. For more information about victim advocacy visit the [link https://www.gvsu.edu/cwge/, placeholder: Center for Women and Gender Equity].
  Students can schedule an appointment with the Victim Advocate by calling [phone 616-331-2748].

 Additionally, the University Counseling Center provides individual and group counseling to sexual assault survivors.  Additional information is available on [link https://gvsu.thrivingcampus.com/, placeholder: the University Counseling Center’s network of community mental health providers, Thriving Campus]
 or by calling [phone 616-331-3266].
 If a student reveals a recent sexual assault and is in crisis, please click the “I Have an Emergency” button. /n You may be required to report what was disclosed as a University employee. For more information about Title IX reporting for faculty and staff, please visit the Office for [link https://www.gvsu.edu/titleix/#:~:text=The%20Office%20of%20Civil%20Rights%20and%20Title%20IX%20serves%20as,oversees%20the%20university%27s%20grievance%20process, placeholder: Office of Civil Rights and Title IX website].
 If someone has disclosed to you a sexual assault or trauma, consider the following tips:
- Thank them for trusting you
- Allow them to share without prodding or asking unnecessary questions
- Avoid giving advice or saying things like, “That wouldn’t have happened if. . .” or “You should have. . . ”
- Tell them that you are sorry about what happened to them
- Offer your support and resources to help them cope

tiles.question: If a student shares something in confidence, is it ok for me to tell someone else if I am concerned?
tiles.answer: Because they interact with students regularly, faculty and staff are often the first to notice concerning changes in students’ mood or behavior. It is appropriate to consult with the University Counseling Center about student mental health concerns that arise, especially when those concerns involve student safety. This is not a breach of student confidentiality. Our clinical staff can provide you with information to address the situation. If your attempts are not successful, you may file a CARE Report to instigate next steps to ensure student well-being.

tiles.question: What is a CARE Report and when should I file one?
tiles.answer: While attending GVSU, students may experience a variety of concerns, including academic distress, financial insecurity, inability to meet basic needs, physical illness, mental health symptoms, bias incidents, housing instability, relationship difficulties, and disruptive or disturbing behavior, among others. The CARE Team (Coordination, Assistance, Response, and Education) is comprised of professional staff members who support all students through challenges they may experience during their time at GVSU. Please complete a [link https://cm.maxient.com/reportingform.php?GrandValley&layout_id=2, placeholder: CARE Report] if the student needs more assistance than you are able to provide.

tiles.question: I want to make sure the student I referred is safe/got help. Is this possible?
tiles.answer:
As licensed healthcare professionals, the University Counseling Center staff cannot legally share whether a student attended a session or received mental health services. If appropriate to your role and/or the nature of your relationship with the student, we encourage you to check in with them after making a referral. Consider asking:
- How have things been going since we last talked?
- Did you have a chance to talk to anyone yet?

tiles.question: What if I'm worried about someone who is not a student (myself, a faculty or staff member, etc.)?
tiles.answer:
Although the University Counseling Center only provides treatment to currently enrolled students, there are many resources available to others who may be struggling with their mental health. For you and other members of the faculty/staff: 
- If there is an immediate threat to self or others, call 911 or GVPD at [phone 616-331-3255].
- The Human Resources Office offers free mental health services to University employees through Encompass [link https://www.gvsu.edu/hro/].
 For family members or loved ones:
- If there is an immediate threat to self or others, call 911.
- For West Michigan mental health resources, visit Psychology Today [link https://www.psychologytoday.com].

tiles.question: What mental health resources/services does the UCC offer?
tiles.answer:
[link https://www.gvsu.edu/counsel, placeholder: The University Counseling Center] offers a variety of services to suit students’ diverse mental health needs. Services are provided at no cost to currently registered GVSU students and include:
- Short-term individual therapy
- Ongoing group therapy, including general therapy groups, symptom management groups, and support groups
- Substance abuse prevention and treatment
- Community referral 
- Mental health prevention and education
- Online self-help tools and resources
- Consultation for concerned students, faculty, and staff

tiles.question: How long does it take for a student to be seen at the University Counseling Center?
tiles.answer: All first-time student appointments are scheduled within two business days. These screening appointments assess student concerns, identify risk, and connect students with appropriate services, which may include individual counseling, group counseling, symptom management resources, or referral to a community provider. If referred to individual counseling, appointments are generally scheduled no more than two weeks out. Group counseling is available throughout the semester. If students need to be seen more quickly, a counselor will assist them in finding a provider in the community who may better meet their needs.

classRoomTechniques.header: As a higher education professional, you know that some stress is inevitable. In addition to academic stressors, many students experience financial insecurity, family distress, relationship issues, social biases, and physical and mental health conditions, among others.  It’s important to remember that while some stress is to be expected, stress that builds up over time can lead to more serious mental health concerns. The good news is that you can help students, right from your classroom. Consider incorporating the following:

techniques.body:
Mindfulness has been proven to reduce stress. Starting your class with a short 2:00 minute video can help students decrease stress and prepare for learning.
[video: cEqZthCaMpo]
 In addition, you can link to longer videos on Blackboard or in your syllabus and encourage students to utilize them.
[video: sG7DBA-mgFY]

A brief statement in your syllabus can show students that you are supportive of their mental health, while also introducing them to services and reducing stigma around seeking treatment. Below is an example of a statement to include in your syllabus:

"Mental health concerns, including overwhelming stress, excessive worry, difficulty participating in daily activities, and changes in mood, appetite, or sleep patterns, can interfere with your academic performance. It is important to know that Grand Valley State University values your health and wellness and provides services to support your mental health on campus. If you are struggling with your mental health or are concerned for another member of our campus community, I urge you to reach out to the University Counseling Center for resources and available services."

University Counseling Center:
[phone 616-331-3266]
[link https://www.gvsu.edu/counsel/]

When presented with new material and complicated topics, people retain information best when focused and calm.  Consider using brain breaks and focused-attention practices to positively impact students’ emotional wellness and readiness to learn.
- Open up a space on Blackboard where students can share funny videos, memes, pictures, or jokes. Then utilize this material to lighten the mood, and refocus attention in your class.
- Allow time and space for standing up and stretching in the middle of class.
- Utilize a deep breathing exercise at the beginning or middle of class, or before a big test. [video: cEqZthCaMpo]

Supporting students’ emotional well-being is campus-wide responsibility. By openly talking about mental health, you will play an important role in creating a healthier and safer campus community. This can be as simple as using phrases like: 
- Midterms can be stressful. As you prepare, be sure to care of your yourself. 
- Take breaks, eat well, and stay connected with people you care about. And remember, there are services on campus that can help. 
- Let’s take a few moments to “check in” with ourselves. This is a chance for each of us to recognize how we’re feeling and acknowledge any worries or concerns that we have. 
- How are you feeling? What usually helps when you’re stressed/anxious/overwhelmed? And who are your supports? Remember there are mental health services available to you if you’re struggling to manage.

If you have a particularly stressful or difficult lesson planned, encourage students to take part in self-care prior to attending class. 
- Exercise: Not everyone can make it to the gym, but you can encourage students to be active in a way that works for them, such as using online workout videos or exploring the outdoors by foot, bike, or wheelchair. [link https://www.gvsu.edu/rec/, placeholder: Visit Rec and Wellness] for information about staying physically healthy. 
- Sleep: Remind students that sleep is vital to their physical and mental health.  Encourage students to create (and stick to!) a sleep routine.  Sometimes all-nighters can do more harm than good when it comes to retaining information and performing important tasks. The University Counseling Center has information about [link https://www.gvsu.edu/counsel/sleep-313.htm, placeholder: sleep hygiene]. 
- Nutrition: Healthy eating can keep our minds working and alert. There are options on campus to help students eat right for self-care. Remind students to fuel-up with healthy foods before a big test or when they have a long day ahead. Those facing food insecurity can use the on-campus food resource, [link https://www.gvsu.edu/replenish/, placeholder: Replenish], as well. 
- Boundaries: A lot of students struggle to say “no” to family, friends, and opportunities for fun in college. Learning to say no can be difficult, but it is important for students to protect their time and energy. Empower students to say no for self-care! The University Counseling Center has more information about [link https://www.gvsu.edu/counsel/healthy-relationships-309.htm, placeholder: healthy relationships and boundaries].
